text: After Afghanistan launched a cross-border attack on Pakistan in Bajaur, tensions escalated as Pakistani forces retaliated, leading to a full-scale incursion into Afghanistan, advancing to the Kunar River.Rashid, Ahmed. Descent into Chaos: The US and the Failure of Nation Building in Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Central Asia. Penguin Books, 2012, pp. 120-123.Giustozzi, Antonio. AFGHANISTAN: TRANSITION WITHOUT END. London School of Economics, 2008, pp. 45-47. https://www.lse.ac.uk/international- development/Assets/Documents/PDFs/csrc-working-papers-phase- two/wp40.2-afghanistan-transition-without-end.pdf The conflict showcased Pakistani military strategy and geopolitical tensions, with Afghan defense led by Khan Mohammad Khan. The battle along the border was fierce, highlighting historical rivalries and territorial disputes. Despite initial successes, Afghan forces faced challenges, prompting international diplomatic efforts to de-escalate and avoid further instability in the region.Kakar, H. M. Government and Society in Afghanistan: The Reign of Amir Abd al-Rahman Khan. Curzon Press, 2006, pp. 312-315.Barfield, Thomas. Afghanistan: A Cultural and Political History. Princeton University Press, 2010, pp. 180-185.Dupree, Louis. Afghanistan. Princeton University Press, 1973, pp. 201-205. Pakistani casualties during the conflict included over 500 killed and 254 captured by Afghan forces. ==References==
title: 1961 Kunar River Incursion
